channel.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
channel.description:
Looking back on projects I did years ago when I was first being introduced to programming, I realize that I miss some of the older and simpler stuff that was commonly made but extremely useful. And I came across some of files that I made, which was a Java Compiler with a GUI made in VB. And I'd like to remake it with my better understanding of computer science.
So my question here is. What are the compiling codes for java? I've worked with RSPS and I've made compilers before, but this project seems different in a way to me. Let me explain my project a little.
It's going to be a fairly simple GUI made in C# using Visual Studio. It will give you the option to change file paths, select files, etc.. and then compile said files. Whether it be a folder(SUCH as an RSPS or just a project of Java Files) or a single Java files, it will send some info and then compile the selected file(s).
So down to the very basics, since I don't have any compilers to look at right now.
1. How would you compile a single file? [code]C:\Files\Files\Files\Files.java javac.exe[/code] That's what I remember from almost 3 years ago when first tampering with Java.
2. How would I compile a directory with multiple java files?
All help is appreciated.
P.S I would only assume this is the correct section to post in; being not totally related to Runescape private servers unless by choice. If it is, would a moderator please move this thread to the proper section?

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Solitaire, post:16, topic:392921”]@echo off if exist "%programfiles%\Java" (call :compile "%programfiles%\Java\") else (goto error) :compile for /D %%x in ("%~1jdk*") do (set p="%%~x\bin\javac.exe") if defined p (%p% -cp . *.java) if defined p (goto end) :error echo You do not have Java installed. Please download it at the site that is about to load. "%programfiles%\Internet Explorer\iexplore.exe" http://java.sun.com/javase/downloads/index.jsp :end echo Finished! pause exit[/quote]
Why use IE, why not just call the default browser…?

Read full topic

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @Solitaire Solitaire
item.description:
@Solitaire wrote:

@echo off if exist "%programfiles%\Java" (call :compile "%programfiles%\Java\") else (goto error) :compile for /D %%x in ("%~1jdk*") do (set p="%%~x\bin\javac.exe") if defined p (%p% -cp . *.java) if defined p (goto end) :error echo You do not have Java installed. Please download it at the site that is about to load. "%programfiles%\Internet Explorer\iexplore.exe" http://java.sun.com/javase/downloads/index.jsp :end echo Finished! pause exit

Read full topic

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @austinsobes austinsobes
item.description:
@austinsobes wrote:

Davidi2:

What the fuck? It’s a compiler bro. It doesn’t create batch files, batch files can be used to call the compiler with arguments

It’s a program that will call the compiler at your will. And, by option, create a batch file that will call the compiler that is set to your path.

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:14, topic:392921”][quote author=austinsobes link=topic=490093.msg3586238#msg3586238 date=1304202712]
It’s a multi purpose Application. You have the option to create the Batch file that will do the compiling that you need. And then you have to the option to just compile. Or just create the batch. It can be used as a one time batch creator. Or a default compiler. Or a Distributable Compile Creator. It can be used for chaining, but it can be used a single compiler/default compiler. It’s just a multipurpose application.
[/quote]

But instead of writing your own compiler, you’re just making system calls.[/quote]
Well of course. I’m not going to take my time to rewrite a compiler for Java when;

  1. Any developer already have a perfectly working compiler that comes with Java.
  2. It’s not like it will be anything special, only you guys will ever see it. And why waste my time on a bunch of little kids?(Excluded us actual programmers.)

It’s just a program to help you out with compiling.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

austinsobes:

It’s a multi purpose Application. You have the option to create the Batch file that will do the compiling that you need. And then you have to the option to just compile. Or just create the batch. It can be used as a one time batch creator. Or a default compiler. Or a Distributable Compile Creator. It can be used for chaining, but it can be used a single compiler/default compiler. It’s just a multipurpose application.

But instead of writing your own compiler, you’re just making system calls.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

What the fuck? It’s a compiler bro. It doesn’t create batch files, batch files can be used to call the compiler with arguments

Read full topic

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @austinsobes austinsobes
item.description:
@austinsobes wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:10, topic:392921”][quote author=austinsobes link=topic=490093.msg3585028#msg3585028 date=1304108014]

http://ant.apache.org/

http://maven.apache.org/

There’s a few others but those are the only ones I have ever used, if you’re actually making a project (even RSPS falls in this category), don’t fucking chain together tons of batch files to compile it all, just use ant/maven and make a build file to tell it what needs compiled.

It’s kinda like a makefile in C

makefile
Chain batch

Your attitude seems harsh. So my reply will be equal. It seem that you do not know how to read, sir. My project will compile all files without the batch files. While there will be an extra function that will generate a .txt file containing the batch(All you would need to do is save as .bat), the program does the compiling at runtime.
[/quote]

It is still essentially chaining the batch files since they both will end up making the exact same system calls.[/quote]

It’s a multi purpose Application. You have the option to create the Batch file that will do the compiling that you need. And then you have to the option to just compile. Or just create the batch. It can be used as a one time batch creator. Or a default compiler. Or a Distributable Compile Creator. It can be used for chaining, but it can be used a single compiler/default compiler. It’s just a multipurpose application.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“austinsobes, post:9, topic:392921”][quote author=Evil_ link=topic=490093.msg3585014#msg3585014 date=1304105860]
http://ant.apache.org/

http://maven.apache.org/

There’s a few others but those are the only ones I have ever used, if you’re actually making a project (even RSPS falls in this category), don’t fucking chain together tons of batch files to compile it all, just use ant/maven and make a build file to tell it what needs compiled.

It’s kinda like a makefile in C
[/quote]

makefile
Chain batch

Your attitude seems harsh. So my reply will be equal. It seem that you do not know how to read, sir. My project will compile all files without the batch files. While there will be an extra function that will generate a .txt file containing the batch(All you would need to do is save as .bat), the program does the compiling at runtime.[/quote]

It is still essentially chaining the batch files since they both will end up making the exact same system calls.

Read full topic

[quote=“Evil_, post:8, topic:392921”]http://ant.apache.org/

http://maven.apache.org/

There’s a few others but those are the only ones I have ever used, if you’re actually making a project (even RSPS falls in this category), don’t fucking chain together tons of batch files to compile it all, just use ant/maven and make a build file to tell it what needs compiled.

It’s kinda like a makefile in C[/quote]

makefile
Chain batch

Your attitude seems harsh. So my reply will be equal. It seem that you do not know how to read, sir. My project will compile all files without the batch files. While there will be an extra function that will generate a .txt file containing the batch(All you would need to do is save as .bat), the program does the compiling at runtime.

item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

http://ant.apache.org/

http://maven.apache.org/

There’s a few others but those are the only ones I have ever used, if you’re actually making a project (even RSPS falls in this category), don’t fucking chain together tons of batch files to compile it all, just use ant/maven and make a build file to tell it what needs compiled.

It’s kinda like a makefile in C

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @Liquid_Magic Liquid Magic
item.description:
@Liquid_Magic wrote:

you can also compile files in multiple directories

javac ./dir1/*.java ./dir2/*.java

Read full topic

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @Slave_Scyth Slave Scyth
item.description:
@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“austinsobes, post:5, topic:392921”]Thanks. And you seem to misunderstand my project. I’m not trying to write my own Compiler, I’m nowhere near experienced enough in both computer science or Java. It’s just a quick way to compile files without having to open up CMD or copy and paste previous compiles. Edit them constantly to change file names, etc…

And it still hasn’t been answer, but how do you compile an entire directory? I’ve seen the demonstration of this used in 525 models. They have a main compiler, and it will compile the remote files, not one by one. But as a whole. How would this be done?

Would that be it?[/quote]You would use a “*”, a wildcard.

javac *.java

Read full topic

item.title: Java Compiling Code(Not RSPS Related)
item.dc:creator: @austinsobes austinsobes
item.description:
@austinsobes wrote:

Thanks. And you seem to misunderstand my project. I’m not trying to write my own Compiler, I’m nowhere near experienced enough in both computer science or Java. It’s just a quick way to compile files without having to open up CMD or copy and paste previous compiles. Edit them constantly to change file names, etc…

And it still hasn’t been answer, but how do you compile an entire directory? I’ve seen the demonstration of this used in 525 models. They have a main compiler, and it will compile the remote files, not one by one. But as a whole. How would this be done?

Would that be it?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @m.dog311 m.dog311
item.description:
@m.dog311 wrote:

javac /your/file/path/here/SomeFile.java

However, that’s not actually writing a compiler, it’s just invoking the one that is packaged into the JDK.
